description: Alteration of earlier sailer, from Middle English sailer, sayler, saylere, equivalent to sail +‎ -or. Cognate with German Segler (“sailor”). Eclipsed non-native Middle English marinel, marynell (“sailor”) borrowed from Old French marinel (“sailor”). See mariner.

entries.meaning: A person in the business of navigating ships or other vessels
Someone knowledgeable in the practical management of ships.
examples: He's a talented sailor and has spent many years at sea.

entries.meaning: A member of the crew of a vessel; a mariner; a common seaman.
A person who sails sailing boats as a sport or recreation.
Any of various nymphalid butterflies of the genera Neptis, Pseudoneptis and Phaedyma, having white markings on a dark base and commonly flying by gliding.
